Detailed Description

All packets look like this.

Only the data is actually sent; the rest is just housekeeping.

Member Function Documentation

void Mercury::Packet::addRequest ( Offset  messageStart,
Offset  nextRequestLink 
)

This method is called to inform the Packet that a new request has been added.

It updates the 'next request offset' linkage as necessary. The value passed in is the offset of the message header.

void Mercury::Packet::addToStream ( BinaryOStream &  data,
const Packet *  pPacket,
int  state 
) [static]

This method writes this packet to the provided stream.

This is used when offloading entity channels and the buffered and unacked packets need to be streamed too. Packets are streamed slightly differently depending on whether they were buffered receives or unacked sends.

static int Mercury::Packet::maxCapacity (  )  [inline, static]

This method returns the maximum possible body size for a single packet.

It does not take into account packetFilter reservations or footers, so should only be used as a rough guide for payload size.

template<class TYPE>
void Mercury::Packet::packFooter ( TYPE  value  )  [inline]

This method writes a footer to the back of this packet.

It should only be called from NetworkInterface::send() and assumes that size_ has been artificially increased so that it points to the end of the footers, the idea being that we work back towards the real body end.

Field& Mercury::Packet::piggyFooters (  )  [inline]

bool Mercury::Packet::processPiggybackPackets ( PacketVisitor &  visitor  ) 

This method extracts and visits any piggybacked packets that are on this packet.

int Mercury::Packet::recvFromEndpoint ( Endpoint &  ep,
Address &  addr 
)

This method does a recv on the endpoint into this packet's data array, setting the length correctly on a successful receive.

The return value is the return value from the low-level recv() call.

template<class TYPE>
bool Mercury::Packet::stripFooter ( TYPE &  value  )  [inline]

This method strips a footer off the back of this packet.

If the use of a switch is a performance issue, this can be reimplemented as a macro. It returns true if there was enough data on the packet for the footer.

bool Mercury::Packet::validateChecksum (  ) 

This method strips and validates the checksum on this packet.

Returns:
true is successful.

void Mercury::Packet::writeChecksum ( Checksum *  pChecksum  ) 

This method writes the checksum into the packet.

Parameters:
pChecksum The pointer to the location of the checksum in the packet's data. Everything up to this location is included in the checksum.

Member Data Documentation

const int Mercury::Packet::HEADER_SIZE = sizeof( Flags ) [static]

The size of the header on a packet.

const int Mercury::Packet::MAX_ACKS = (1 << (8 * sizeof( AckCount ))) - 1 [static]

The maximum number of ACKs that can fit on a single packet.

const int Mercury::Packet::RESERVED_FOOTER_SIZE [static]

Initial value:

        sizeof( Offset ) + 
        sizeof( AckCount ) + 
        sizeof( SeqNum ) + 
        sizeof( SeqNum ) * 2 + 
        sizeof( ChannelID ) + sizeof( ChannelVersion ) + 
        sizeof( Checksum )
The amount of space that is reserved for fixed-length footers on a packet.

This is done so that the bundle logic can always assume that these footers will fit and not have to worry about pre-allocating them. This is currently 27 bytes, roughly 1.5% of the capacity of a packet, so there's not too much wastage.
